entry.title: FFXIV Expert Crafting Guide — Overview, Conditions, and Principles

link.title: FFXIV Expert Crafting Guide — Overview, Conditions, and Principles

entry.content:
If you wish to make an apple pie from scratch, you must first invent the universe.
— Carl Sagan

Expert Crafting

Expert crafting exists to remove the illusion that crafting in Final Fantasy XIV is solved. These recipes were designed to resist macro automation, enforce resource awareness, and reward the crafter who understands why an action is chosen rather than merely when.

While later expansions have softened the gear requirements and expanded available tools, the underlying structure of expert crafts has remained intact. Success is not determined by memorization, but by adaptation.

This guide outlines the systems that govern expert crafting and the principles that make it manageable.

What Makes a Craft “Expert”

Expert recipes differ from standard crafts in three important ways:

  • Higher quality ceilings, requiring deliberate quality investment
  • Unpredictable conditions, replacing Excellent and Poor
  • Narrow margins, where mismanagement compounds quickly

These elements shift the focus from execution to evaluation. Every step asks a question. The craft ends when you stop answering them correctly.

Conditions

Expert crafting replaces traditional condition states with five specialized statuses. These conditions are the primary source of variance and opportunity.

There are no Excellent or Poor conditions. Instead, the following states appear:

Centered

Increases action success rate by 25%.

Centered reduces risk. It does not increase output, but it enables consistency when using actions with failure chance.

Sturdy

Reduces durability loss by 50%.

Sturdy stacks multiplicatively with effects such as Waste Not, allowing extended setup and safer progress advancement.

Pliant

Reduces CP cost by 50%.

Pliant is the primary window for high-efficiency CP spending. Poor use of this condition often leads to late-stage instability.

Malleable

Increases progress gains by 1.5×.

Malleable multiplies progress bonuses rather than adding to them. While powerful, it must be managed carefully to avoid premature completion.

Primed

Extends the duration of the next status applied by an action by 2 additional steps.

Primed rewards foresight. Its value depends entirely on what follows.

Condition Usage Matrix

Condition Primary Use Case Common Misuse
Centered Risk reduction Treated as a payoff window
Sturdy Durability extension Ignored or underutilized
Pliant High-cost action deployment CP overspending without plan
Malleable Controlled progress gain Accidental craft completion
Primed Buff extension setup Immediate low-value action

Conditions should be leveraged deliberately, not reflexively.

Resources and Constraints

Expert crafting is governed by three finite resources:

  • Durability
  • CP
  • Remaining progress

These resources are interdependent. The purpose of most actions is not immediate gain, but future flexibility.

A craft typically fails when one resource collapses before the others can compensate.

Resource Interaction Table

Resource When Healthy When Failing Typical Result
Durability Allows setup and recovery Limits remaining decisions Forced finish
CP Enables adaptation Removes flexibility Low quality
Progress Under controlled threshold Accidentally completed or lagging Premature end

The Expert Crafting Decision Loop

Expert crafting is best understood as a repeated evaluation cycle. Each step narrows the set of acceptable actions.

graph TD
A[New Step] --> B[Check Progress]
B --> C[Check Durability]
C --> D[Check CP]
D --> E[Check Condition]
E --> F[Select Action]
F --> A

Skipping any node in this loop introduces instability.

Quality Phase

The Quality Phase is the most cognitively demanding portion of an expert craft. The objective is to reach 11 stacks of Inner Quiet while preserving CP and durability. This phase rewards pattern recognition rather than speed.

graph LR
A[Inner Quiet not active] --> B[Apply Inner Quiet]
B --> C{Check Condition}

C -->|Normal or Malleable| D[Prudent Touch]
C -->|Centered| D
C -->|Sturdy| D
C -->|Pliant| E[Manipulation]
C -->|Primed| F[Innovation]
C -->|Good| G[Precise Touch]

G --> H{Inner Quiet at 11?}
H -->|No| C
H -->|Yes| I[Prepare for Cash-Out]

Quality Spending Heuristic

Situation Recommended Action
Neutral or poor condition Setup or stabilize
Favorable condition + CP buffer High-impact quality
Low CP, high durability Guaranteed value
Low durability Stop gambling

Quality is not accumulated continuously. It is harvested selectively.

Progress Management

Progress should be advanced deliberately. Overshooting progress is a common and costly error.

graph LR
A[Progress Behind] --> B[Use Progress Action]
B --> C[Re-evaluate Progress]

A -->|Malleable| D[Strong Progress Action]
D --> C

C --> E{Near Completion?}
E -->|No| A
E -->|Yes| F[Precision Progress Only]

Progress Control Thresholds

Progress State Recommended Behavior
Far from complete Safe setup, condition fishing
Mid-range Controlled progress advances
Near completion Precision actions only
Finish-ready Commit intentionally

Overshooting progress is not a timing error. It is a planning failure.

Durability Recovery

Durability recovery increases available decision space. Its value lies not in the recovery itself, but in what the recovered steps enable.

Recovery without purpose frequently results in wasted resources.

Failure Recovery Decision Tree

graph LR
A[Craft Destabilizing] --> B{Durability Low?}
B -->|Yes| C[Recover Durability]
B -->|No| D{CP Low?}

D -->|Yes| E[Guaranteed Value Actions]
D -->|No| F{Progress Risk?}

F -->|Yes| G[Stabilize Progress]
F -->|No| H[Resume Normal Loop]

Post-Endwalker vs Ishgard Restoration Expert Crafting

Although the mechanics of expert crafting remain consistent, the experience differs notably between the Ishgard Restoration era and post-Endwalker content.

Ishgard Restoration Era

  • Strict gear and meld requirements
  • Tight CP margins
  • Limited recovery tools
  • Failure often irreversible

Post-Endwalker Era

  • Higher baseline stats
  • Expanded recovery options
  • Greater tolerance for mistakes
  • Overconfidence becomes the primary risk

The system remains intact; only the margins have widened.

Common Failure Patterns

  • Early overcommitment
  • Accidental progress completion
  • Condition tunnel vision

Failure Diagnosis Table

Symptom Root Cause
Ran out of CP Early overcommitment
Finished too early Uncontrolled progress
High durability, low quality Missed condition exploitation
Sudden collapse No recovery buffer

Practice and Improvement

Improvement comes from post-run analysis rather than repetition.

After each failure, identify:

  • Which resource failed first
  • Why recovery was no longer possible

Closing Thoughts

Expert crafting is not designed to be comfortable. It exists to reward patience, awareness, and restraint.

When the craft feels difficult, it is functioning as intended.

Mastery comes when the process feels conversational rather than chaotic.

This guide focuses on system understanding rather than patch-specific rotations.
entry.summary: FFXIV expert crafting explained: what makes a craft expert, condition usage matrix, and principles for adaptation over memorization.

entry.title: Pilgrims Traverse 1-20 Guide — FFXIV Dawntrail Deep Dungeon Floorset

link.title: Pilgrims Traverse 1-20 Guide — FFXIV Dawntrail Deep Dungeon Floorset

entry.content:
Deep Dungeon PT 1-20 — Floorset Guide

This guide covers Floors 1–20 of Pilgrims Traverse, split into two difficulty bands. Early floors introduce mechanics safely, while Floors 11–20 escalate damage, enemy density, and mimic risk.

PT 1-10 Overview

Floors Rooms Enemies Chests Mimics Hoard Reward
1-10 3-6 2-3 4-6 Bronze chests on 7-10 Sack of Silvered Light

Respawn Timer: 1 minute

Key Notes

  • Floors 1-6 have no bronze chests, therefore no mimics.
  • Floors 1-6 do not drop:
    • Alteration
    • Purity
    • Serenity
    • Purification
    • Raising
    • Devotion
  • Silver chests can drop incense starting on Floor 1.
  • Pomanders of Affluence, Flight, and Alteration do not drop on Floor 9.
  • Bronze chests in this set do not drop potsherds.

Early floors can hurt through overlapping AoEs but rarely kill outright. Mimic Deathtrap is the only lethal mechanic introduced here and only appears later in the set.

PT 1-10 Enemy Highlights

Enemy Floors Agro Notes
Traverse Morpho 1-2 Sight AoE Incubus inflicts Sleep
Traverse Echevore 1-3 Sight Line AoE Leafcutter
Traverse Shrub (Patrol) 1-3 Sight Patrol with line AoE
Traverse Phooka 1-4 Sight Interruptible Tornado
Traverse Hawker 2-5 Sight Fast mover
Traverse Moss Fungus 3-6 Proximity Spores and slow effects
Traverse Lorikeet 4-7 Sight Dive AoEs
Traverse Rowan 5-8 Sight Cleaves
Traverse Clematis 6-9 Proximity Point-blank AoE
Traverse Killer Bee 7-10 Proximity Poison stacks
Traverse Rosebear 8-10 Proximity High physical damage
Traverse Basket 9-10 Sight Summons adds
Traverse Etainmoth 9-10 Proximity Interruptible gust AoE

Most enemies here are vulnerable to bind, heavy, sleep, slow, and stun.

PT 11-20 Overview

Floors Rooms Enemies Chests Mimics Hoard Reward
11-20 3-6 2-3 4-6 Bronze chests 11-19 Sack of Silvered Light

Respawn Timer: 1 minute

Key Notes

  • Mimics can appear from bronze chests on Floors 11-19.
  • Floors 11-13 do not drop potsherds from bronze chests.
  • Pomanders of Affluence, Flight, and Alteration do not drop on Floor 19.
  • Damage ramps significantly compared to PT 1-10.

This floorset introduces more patrols, sound-based agro, tighter room spacing, and higher punishment for mistakes.

PT 11-20 Enemy Highlights

Enemy Floors Agro Notes
Traverse Puck (Tenaga) 11-12 Sound Line AoE
Forgiven Ignorance (Miteling) 11-13 Sight Knockback line
Traverse Tot Aevis (Patrol) 11-13 Sight Conal AoE
Forgiven Conformity (Hound) 11-14 Sight Fast autos
Traverse Peaseblossom 13-15 Sight Circular AoE
Forgiven Folly (Mite) 14-15 Sight Point-blank AoE
Forgiven Deceit (Patrol) 14-16 Sight Conal fire
Traverse Topiary 15-17 Sight Instant attacks
Forgiven Disobedience (Dzo) 16-17 Sight Line charge
Forgiven Complacency 16-19 Sight Shadow AoE
Forgiven Contempt (Patrol) 17-19 Sight Fire breath
Forgiven Conceit 18-19 Sight Heavy conal
Forgiven Violence 18-19 Sight High damage AoE
Mimic 11-19 Proximity Deathtrap on chest open

Enemy telegraphs are faster and overlap more frequently than PT 1-10.

Strategy Summary

PT 1-10

  • Learn enemy tells and spacing.
  • Open chests freely on Floors 1-6.
  • Save mitigation for Floors 7-10 if mimics appear.

PT 11-20

  • Treat every bronze chest as dangerous.
  • Track patrol paths before pulling.
  • Save utility pomanders ahead of Floor 19.
  • Interrupt or stun aggressively to reduce damage spikes.
entry.summary: Pilgrims Traverse floors 1-20 guide: enemy highlights, chests, mimics, and hoard rewards for FFXIV Dawntrail deep dungeon.

entry.title: FFXIV Splendorous Gathering Tools Complete Guide - All 6 Stages (MIN/BTN/FSH)

link.title: FFXIV Splendorous Gathering Tools Complete Guide - All 6 Stages (MIN/BTN/FSH)

entry.content:
Introduction

Splendorous Gathering Tools are the level 90+ relic tools for Disciples of the Land (Miner, Botanist, Fisher), introduced in patch 6.35 and expanded through Dawntrail. This comprehensive guide covers all six upgrade stages from base Splendorous Tools to the final Lodestar Tools.

What You’ll Learn:

  • Unlock requirements and prerequisites
  • All 6 upgrade stages with locations and collectables
  • Efficient gathering rotations for max collectability
  • Fishing strategies and bait requirements
  • Aetherial Reduction mechanics (Stages 3-6)

Total Time Investment: 10-20 hours per job (faster than crafters)
Total Scrip Cost: ~2,000-3,000 Purple Scrips per job

Note: Purple Scrips are officially called “Purple Gatherer’s Scrips” for Disciples of the Land. They appear purple in-game despite sometimes being referred to as “White Scrips” in older content.

Quick Reference: All Tool Stages

Stage Tool Name MIN/BTN Requirement FSH Requirement Scrip Cost
0 Splendorous Tool Quest reward (first free) Quest reward 1,500 per job
1 Augmented Splendorous 60 collectables (180 components) 120 fish ~600 (bait)
2 Crystalline Tool 70 collectables (210 components) 160 fish ~800 (bait)
3 Chora-Zoi’s Crystalline ~55 items → reduce (210 components) 160 fish ~800 (bait)
4 Brilliant Tool ~55 items → reduce (210 components) 160 fish ~800 (bait)
5 Vrandtic Visionary’s ~95 items → reduce (220 components) 170 fish ~850 (bait)
6 Lodestar Tool (Final) ~95 items → reduce (220 components) 170 fish ~850 (bait)

Prerequisites & Unlock

Requirements

Before starting, you must have:

  • Level 90+ Disciple of the Land (Miner, Botanist, or Fisher)
  • Completed Endwalker Main Scenario Quest
  • Unlocked The Crystalline Mean (Crystarium feature quest)
  • Unlocked Collectables system

Unlock Quest

Quest: An Original Improvement
NPC: Chora-Zoi
Location: The Crystarium (X:7.8, Y:11.4)

Reward: Splendorous Coffer (contains tool for your current job)

Stage 0: Acquiring Base Splendorous Tools

First Tool (Free)

Complete “An Original Improvement” to receive your first Splendorous Coffer. Open it on the gathering job you want the tool for.

Additional Tools (1,500 Purple Scrips Each)

Purchase from Quinnana in The Crystarium (X:10.4, Y:7.7).

Available Tools:

  • Miner: Splendorous Pickaxe
  • Botanist: Splendorous Hatchet
  • Fisher: Splendorous Fishing Rod

Budget Planning: If doing all 3 gathering jobs, you’ll need 3,000 Purple Scrips for base tools (first is free).

Essential Gathering Information

Recommended Consumables

Food: Rarefied Tsai tou Vonou (HQ) or any level 90+ HQ food

  • +10% GP boost
  • Helps meet collectability thresholds

GP Recovery: Hi-Cordial or Cordial

  • Essential for continuous gathering
  • Keep 99 in inventory

Collectability Requirements

Miner & Botanist:

  • Stages 1-2: Max collectability (1,000) recommended
  • Stages 3-6: Max collectability required for Aetherial Reduction

Fisher:

  • Enable Collector’s Glove (Collect ability)
  • Higher collectability = more components per fish

Gathering Rotations (MIN/BTN)

Max Collectability Rotation (400 GP)

Use this rotation when you have 400+ GP:

1
2

Scrutiny → Meticulous Prospector → Scrutiny → 
Meticulous Prospector → Meticulous Prospector → Collect

Result: 1,000 collectability guaranteed

GP Recovery Rotation (Less than 400 GP)

Use this when waiting for GP to regenerate:

1

Brazen Prospector → Brazen Prospector → Brazen Prospector → Collect

Result: Lower collectability, but keeps you gathering

Hidden Items Strategy

All stages have hidden items (crystals/clusters):

  • Miner: Use Luck of the Mountaineer
  • Botanist: Use Luck of the Pioneer

Pro Tip: Gather hidden items whenever they appear to conserve GP. They count toward your component total without requiring collectability rotations.

Fishing Strategies

Required Item

Select Bait Ball - Purchase from Quinnana for 5 Purple Scrips each

How many to buy:

  • Stage 1: ~25 bait (120 fish needed)
  • Stage 2: ~35 bait (160 fish needed)
  • Stages 3-6: ~35 bait each (160-170 fish per stage)

Total for all 6 stages: ~200 bait = 1,000 Purple Scrips

Fishing Rotation for Efficiency

Before casting: Enable Collector’s Glove (Collect ability)

Optimal fishing combo:

1

Identical Cast → Double Hook → Thaliak's Favor

With Cordials: Use Hi-Cordial between casts to maintain GP

Result: Doubles your catch rate, reducing time significantly

Stage 1: Augmented Splendorous Tools

Quest Details

Quest: A Dedicated Tool (Repeatable)
NPC: Chora-Zoi
Location: The Crystarium (X:10.5, Y:7.7)
Requirement: Splendorous Tool equipped or in inventory

Miner: Augmented Splendorous Pickaxe

Location: Il Mheg (X:11.0, Y:36.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Prismstone (60 items at max collectability)
  • Splendorous Water Shard (180 hidden items)

Turn-in: 180 Splendorous Miner’s Components to Quinnana

Time: 1-2 hours

Botanist: Augmented Splendorous Hatchet

Location: Kholusia (X:25.0, Y:12.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Wattle Petribark (60 items at max collectability)
  • Splendorous Earth Shard (180 hidden items)

Turn-in: 180 Splendorous Botanist’s Components to Quinnana

Time: 1-2 hours

Fisher: Augmented Splendorous Fishing Rod

Location 1: Lakeland (X:21.2, Y:29.7)

  • Fish: Platinum Seahorse
  • Components: Splendorous Fishing Rod Component

Location 2: Kholusia (X:16.0, Y:35.0)

  • Fish: Clavekeeper
  • Components: Splendorous Fishing Reel Component

Bait: Select Bait Ball (5 scrips each)

Total Needed: 120 fish (60 from each location)

Time: 1-2 hours

Stage 2: Crystalline Tools

Quest Details

Quest: An Adaptive Tool (Repeatable)
NPC: Chora-Zoi
Location: The Crystarium (X:10.5, Y:7.7)
Requirement: Augmented Splendorous Tool in inventory

Miner: Crystalline Pickaxe

Location: Amh Araeng (X:28.0, Y:14.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Red Malachite (70 items at max collectability)
  • Adaptive Fire Crystal (210 hidden items)

Turn-in: 210 Adaptive Miner’s Components to Quinnana

Botanist: Crystalline Hatchet

Location: Lakeland (X:34.0, Y:10.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Levin Mint (70 items at max collectability)
  • Adaptive Lightning Crystal (210 hidden items)

Turn-in: 210 Adaptive Botanist’s Components to Quinnana

Fisher: Crystalline Fishing Rod

Location 1: Il Mheg (X:4.0, Y:22.0)

  • Fish: Mirror Image
  • Components: Adaptive Fishing Rod Component

Location 2: The Rak’tika Greatwood (X:7.0, Y:28.0)

  • Fish: Spangled Pirarucu
  • Components: Adaptive Fishing Reel Component

Bait: Select Bait Ball

Total Needed: 160 fish (80 from each location)

Stage 3: Chora-Zoi’s Crystalline Tools

Quest Details

Quest: A Tool of Her Own (Repeatable)
NPC: Chora-Zoi (speak to Grenoldt first to complete “The Joy of Zoi”)
Location: The Crystarium (X:10.5, Y:7.7)
Requirement: Crystalline Tool in inventory

NEW MECHANIC: Aetherial Reduction

Stages 3-6 use Aetherial Reduction instead of direct turn-ins.

How it works:

  1. Gather collectable at max collectability (1,000)
  2. Right-click the collectable in your inventory
  3. Select “Aetherial Reduction”
  4. Receive 3-6 components per reduction

Why this matters: You need ~55 items to get 210 components (vs 70 items in Stage 2)

Miner: Chora-Zoi’s Crystalline Pickaxe

Location: Lakeland (X:17.0, Y:15.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Soiled Femur (~55 items)
  • Custom Ice Crystal (210 hidden items)

Reduce for: 210 Customized Miner’s Components

Botanist: Chora-Zoi’s Crystalline Hatchet

Location: Il Mheg (X:26.0, Y:19.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Miracle Apple (~55 items)
  • Custom Wind Crystal (210 hidden items)

Reduce for: 210 Customized Botanist’s Components

Fisher: Chora-Zoi’s Crystalline Fishing Rod

Location 1: Amh Araeng (X:31.0, Y:32.0)

  • Fish: Gold Dustfish
  • Components: Customized Fishing Rod Component

Location 2: Lakeland (X:10.0, Y:38.0)

  • Fish: Forgiven Melancholy
  • Components: Customized Fishing Reel Component

Bait: Select Bait Ball

Total Needed: 160 fish (80 from each location)

Stage 4: Brilliant Tools

Quest Details

Quest: A Tool without Compare (Repeatable)
NPC: Chora-Zoi
Requirement: Chora-Zoi’s Crystalline Tool in inventory

Miner: Brilliant Pickaxe

Location: Kholusia (X:33.0, Y:29.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Aurum Regis Ore (~55 items)
  • Brilliant Lightning Cluster (210 hidden items)

Reduce for: 210 Brilliant Miner’s Components

Botanist: Brilliant Hatchet

Location: Amh Araeng (X:18.0, Y:19.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Cloves (~55 items)
  • Brilliant Earth Cluster (210 hidden items)

Reduce for: 210 Brilliant Botanist’s Components

Fisher: Brilliant Fishing Rod

Location 1: Kholusia (X:29.4, Y:21.4)

  • Fish: Oil Slick
  • Components: Brilliant Fishing Rod Component

Location 2: The Tempest (X:6.0, Y:13.5)

  • Fish: Gonzalo’s Grace
  • Components: Brilliant Fishing Reel Component

Bait: Select Bait Ball

Total Needed: 160 fish (80 from each location)

Stage 5: Vrandtic Visionary’s Tools

Quest Details

Quest: A Tool for the Ages (Repeatable)
NPC: Chora-Zoi (complete “La Vie Mowen” and “Dance Like Mowen is Watching” first)
Requirement: Brilliant Tool equipped

INCREASED COMPONENT REQUIREMENT: 220 components (up from 210)

Miner: Vrandtic Visionary’s Pickaxe

Location: Il Mheg (X:11.6, Y:10.7)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Asphaltum (~95 items)
  • Inspirational Wind Cluster (220 hidden items)

Reduce for: 220 Inspirational Miner’s Components

Botanist: Vrandtic Visionary’s Hatchet

Location: Rak’tika Greatwood (X:15.0, Y:35.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Gianthive Chip (~95 items)
  • Inspirational Fire Cluster (220 hidden items)

Reduce for: 220 Inspirational Botanist’s Components

Fisher: Vrandtic Visionary’s Fishing Rod

Location: The Rak’tika Greatwood (X:25.5, Y:36.7)

Special Fishing Chain (Mooch Required):

  1. Catch Deadwood Shadow (Powerful Hookset)
  2. OR catch Golding (Precision Hookset)
  3. Mooch Golding → Ronkan Bullion (Powerful Hookset)

Components: 170 Inspirational Fisher’s Components

Bait: Select Bait Ball

Note: This is more complex than previous stages due to mooch requirement

Stage 6: Lodestar Tools (Final Stage)

Quest Details

Quest: Stand Tool, My Friend (Repeatable)
NPC: Chora-Zoi
Requirement: Vrandtic Visionary’s Tool equipped

SAME REQUIREMENT AS STAGE 5: 220 components

Miner: Lodestar Pickaxe

Location: The Tempest (X:34.0, Y:22.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Raw Onyx (~95 items)
  • Nightforged Ice Cluster (220 hidden items)

Reduce for: 220 Nightforged Miner’s Components

Botanist: Lodestar Hatchet

Location: The Tempest (X:37.0, Y:13.0)

Collectables:

  • Connoisseur’s Glimshroom (~95 items)
  • Nightforged Water Cluster (220 hidden items)

Reduce for: 220 Nightforged Botanist’s Components

Fisher: Lodestar Fishing Rod

Location: Il Mheg (X:35.0, Y:26.0)

Special Fishing Mechanic (Fisher’s Intuition):

  1. Catch 3x Little Bounty (normal fishing)
  2. This triggers Fisher’s Intuition buff
  3. With buff active, catch Saint Fathric’s Face

Components: 170 Nightforged Fisher’s Components

Bait: Select Bait Ball

Congratulations! You now have your Lodestar Tool - the final stage of the Splendorous gathering relic chain.

Efficient Purple Scrip Farming (Gatherers)

Custom Deliveries (Best Passive Method)

Weekly Reset: Tuesday at 8 AM server time

NPCs: M’naago, Adkiragh, Kai-Shirr, Kurenai, Ameliance, etc.

Scrips per Week: 1,500-2,000 (varies by satisfaction bonus)

Time Investment: 30-60 minutes per week

Strategy: Custom Deliveries alone can complete a gathering relic every 2-3 weeks with zero grinding.

Collectable Gathering (Active Farming)

Any level 90+ collectable works. Choose based on:

  • Node location convenience
  • Short respawn timers
  • Easy rotation requirements

Top Gathering Spots:

  • Labyrinthos nodes (central, clustered)
  • Elpis nodes (flying mount friendly)
  • Ultima Thule nodes (high-level items)

Cost Breakdown: Complete Tool Progression

Per Job Cost (Scrips)

Stage Miner/Botanist Fisher (Bait)
Base Tool 1,500 1,500
Augmented 0 (no scrips) ~125 (25 bait)
Crystalline 0 (no scrips) ~175 (35 bait)
Chora-Zoi’s 0 (no scrips) ~175 (35 bait)
Brilliant 0 (no scrips) ~175 (35 bait)
Vrandtic Visionary’s 0 (no scrips) ~175 (35 bait)
Lodestar 0 (no scrips) ~175 (35 bait)
TOTAL ~1,500 ~2,500

Fisher is more scrip-intensive due to bait costs.

Tips & Strategies

Efficient Progression Path (Miner/Botanist)

Week 1: Custom Deliveries, buy base tool
Week 2: Complete Stages 1-2 (direct turn-ins)
Week 3: Complete Stages 3-4 (aetherial reduction)
Week 4: Complete Stages 5-6 (higher volume reduction)

Total Time: 4 weeks casually, 1 week if grinding

Fisher Optimization

Buy bait in bulk: Purchase 200 Select Bait Balls at start (1,000 scrips)

Use GP efficiently:

  • Identical Cast → Double Hook combo
  • Thaliak’s Favor for rare fish
  • Hi-Cordials between casts

Fish multiple locations: Alternate between rod/reel component fish to prevent burnout

Multi-Job Strategy

Do all 3 gathering jobs together:

  • Buy all base tools (3,000 scrips)
  • Progress through stages simultaneously
  • Share food and cordials across jobs

Benefits:

  • Efficient scrip usage
  • Variety prevents burnout
  • Faster overall completion

Troubleshooting

“I can’t hit max collectability (1,000)”

Solutions:

  • Use HQ food for stat boost
  • Verify you have level 90 left-side gathering gear
  • Use the 400 GP rotation (not the recovery rotation)
  • Meld gathering stat materia if needed

“Aetherial Reduction only gives 3 components”

This is RNG:

  • 3-6 components per reduction is normal
  • Average is ~4 components
  • Plan for ~55-95 items to get required components
  • Hidden items don’t require reduction

“Fishing is taking forever”

Speed improvements:

  • Always use Identical Cast → Double Hook
  • Use Thaliak’s Favor for stubborn fish
  • Keep Hi-Cordials stocked (recover GP faster)
  • Food buff helps catch rate

“I can’t find the gathering node”

Check:

  • Correct expansion zone (Shadowbringers zones)
  • Exact coordinates (not approximate)
  • Time of day (some nodes are time-gated)
  • Flying unlocked in zone

Achievement Rewards

Completing all Lodestar Gathering Tools grants:

  • “Lodestar Luminary” title (all 11 DoH/DoL tools completed)
  • Glamour options for all tool stages
  • Satisfaction of completing endgame gathering relics

Comparison: Gathering vs Crafting Relics

Aspect Gathering Crafting
Time per job 10-20 hours 15-30 hours
Scrip cost 1,500-2,500 10,000-11,000
Difficulty Easy (rotations simple) Medium (macros required stages 5-6)
GP/CP management Easy (cordials) Medium (food/tinctures)
Stages 1-2 Direct turn-ins Direct turn-ins
Stages 3-6 Aetherial Reduction Crafting collectables

Gathering relics are significantly faster and cheaper than crafting relics.

Related Guides

  • FFXIV Splendorous Crafting Tools Guide - Complete DoH relic guide
  • FFXIV Custom Deliveries Guide - Maximize scrip income
  • FFXIV Gathering Rotations Guide - Optimize collectability

The Splendorous/Lodestar Gathering Tools are the fastest relics in FFXIV to complete. Use Custom Deliveries for passive progress, and you’ll have all three gathering relics done in a month with minimal active grinding!

Splendorous Tools are the level 90+ relic tools for Disciples of the Hand and Land, introduced in patch 6.35 and expanded through Dawntrail. This comprehensive guide covers all six upgrade stages from base Splendorous Tools to the final Lodestar Tools.

  • Efficient scrip farming strategies
  • Crafting macros for each stage

Total Time Investment: 15-30 hours per job (varies by playstyle)
Total Scrip Cost: ~4,000-6,000 Purple Scrips per job

Note: Purple Scrips are officially called “Purple Crafter’s Scrips” (for DoH) and “Purple Gatherer’s Scrips” (for DoL). They appear purple in-game despite sometimes being referred to as “White Scrips” in older content.

entry.content:
Hey there, adventurer!

Are you ready to level up your crafting classes in Final Fantasy XIV Endwalker? Look no further; I’ve got you covered with my comprehensive Crafting Guide and Leveling Guide! In this guide, I’ll show you how to quickly level all your crafter classes from 1 to 90. If you’re new to crafting, don’t worry - I’ll provide macros to do most of the heavy lifting. And if you want to skip the grind, I’ll share some tips for buying the gear and materials needed for Grade 4 Ishgard Restoration recipes on the Market Board. With my suggested equipment and macros, you’ll breeze through the leveling process and gain huge EXP bonuses. Whether you choose to level all your classes together or one at a time, I’ve got you covered. Plan your inventory space accordingly, and let’s get crafting!

Prerequisites

Before diving into crafting in Final Fantasy XIV, there are a few prerequisites you need to fulfill to ensure a smooth journey. Here are the essential requirements:

  • Main Class Level 70+: To access The Firmament and begin crafting, you must have your main class at level 70 or above. Additionally, you must have completed the Stormblood Main Scenario to gain access to The Firmament.
  • Tools: Your Main Hand and Off-Hand tools will help carry most of the stat requirements we need to craft. They can easily be purchased from various NPCs in the game. If you don’t have access to the required NPCs, you’ll rely on the Market Board to obtain tools instead.
  • Engineering Manuals: You’ll need access to Engineering Manuals to provide a +50% boost to EXP during Levels 1-21. While these manuals can be used at any level, they are most vital at these levels as nearly all EXP is awarded from crafting. The easiest way to obtain Engineering Manuals is by using Grand Company Seals.
  • HQ Tsai tou Vounou Food: You will need to stock up on High-Quality Tsai tou Vounou, the food of choice for our macros due to their great Control and CP bonuses.
  • 3-5 Million Gil: You’ll need some starting funds to purchase gear, tools, materia, food, and materials to prepare for the journey from 1-80. While these numbers are not absolutely required, it is nice to have! Besides, you don’t mind gathering it all yourself, do you?

In fulfilling these prerequisites, you’ll be well-prepared to embark on your crafting journey and level up your crafter classes from 1-90. This guide can be followed to the end without completing the Shadowbringers or Endwalker Story Quests, thanks to Ishgardian Restoration – Great news for all you players who want to stretch the game out as much as possible!

entry.title: FFXIV Expert Crafting Guide — Conditions, Phases, and Macro-Free Tips

link.title: FFXIV Expert Crafting Guide — Conditions, Phases, and Macro-Free Tips

entry.content:
If you wish to make an apple pie from scratch, you must first invent the universe - Carl Sagan

Expert Crafting

Expert Crafts were originally designed to be some of the most complicated crafts, with Higher than normal Quality maximums and strict gear requirements. With the addition of 6.0 Endwalker, things have certainly gotten easier in time. This guide aims to explain the basics behind Expert Crafting and serve as an entry point for anyone looking to get started or fine tune their process.

Conditions

There are no Excellent or Poor conditions with Expert Crafting, but there are 5 new status conditions to watch out for:

  • Centered - Increases action success rate by 25%
  • Sturdy - Reduces loss of durability by 50% (Can stack with Waste Not)
  • Pliant - Reduces CP cost by 50%
  • Malleable - Increases to progress are 1.5 times higher than normal (be careful, it multiplies not adds on buffs so it’s slightly stronger than veneration)
  • Primed - Next status granted by an action will last 2 additional steps

Crafting Phases

graph LR
A{Opener Phase} --> B{Quality Phase}
B --> C((Finishing Steps))

Opener Phase

The Opener Phase is where you ideally want to build up as much progress as you can, start Inner Quiet, and have Manipulation up depending on your Condition RNG. For this you’ll be focusing on item conditions, using skills and buffs as you make your way towards Progress completion. You’ll want to repeat these steps until you are one progress skill away from completing your craft. It doesn’t matter what skill you use to complete the craft in the Finishing Phase (Basic Synth, Careful Synth, etc.), the key thing to remember is not to complete the craft before completing your Quality Phase!

graph LR
J((Start)) --> A
J --> C
J --> E
J --> G
A[Centered, Sturdy, Primed, Normal] --> B{Rapid Synth}
C[Malleable] -- Final Appraisal --> B
E[Pliant] --> F((Manipulation)) --> I
F -- If Already Used --> K{Inner Quiet}
E -- End of Opener? --> B
G[Good] --> H[Tricks of the Trade] --> I
G -- Max CP? --> B
B --> I((Check Condition))

Quality Phase

The Quality Phase is easily the most complicated portion of these Expert Crafts. Your goal during this portion is to build 11 stacks of Inner Quiet, while maintaining your Crafting Points (CP), and making sure you don’r run out of Durability. Sounds complex, but its actually pretty easy to get into a rhythm once you’re used to seeing Conditions and reacting to them.

graph LR
A[Inner Quiet if not Up Already] --> B{Start}
B --> C[Normal or Malleable]
B --> D[Pliant]
B --> E[Centered]
B --> F[Sturdy]
B --> G[Primed]
B --> H[Good]
C --> I{Prudent Touch}
D --> J{Manipulation}
G --> K{Innovation}
H --> L{Precise Touch}
H -- 11 Stacks of IQ --> M{ToT}

Finisher Phase
